dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there! I see you recently presented 2 weeks after an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy for non-perforated acute appendicitis. How have you been feeling since the surgery?
Patient: Well, I've been having some issues with my urinary frequency. It's reduced to just twice per day and I'm experiencing prolonged hesitancy.
Doctor: I see. Can you describe your micturition stream for me?
Patient: Initially, it was weak and slow, but now it has become interrupted. Straining doesn't seem to help make the stream stronger.
Doctor: Alright. Have you ever suffered from urinary tract infections (UTIs) or constipation before?
Patient: No, I've never had any UTIs or constipation. I usually open my bowels daily.
Doctor: I understand you also had an episode of acute cystitis 2 months later. How was that treated?
Patient: I completely lost my ability to void, so I was put on an indwelling Foley urinary catheter. My cystitis was successfully treated with antibiotics.
Doctor: And what happened after the catheter was removed?
Patient: After every attempt to remove it, I had to be catheterized again, and they registered between 300 to 1200 mL of urine volume.
Doctor: How did that make you feel?
Patient: I lost the urge to urinate and only felt a dull pain in the suprapubic region and right iliac fossa when my bladder was extremely distended.
Doctor: I see you were referred to a tertiary center to determine the cause of your urinary retention. What were the results of your examinations?
Patient: They examined me and found normal clinical findings. They also did an abdominal and pelvic ultrasound scan but didn't find any obvious pathology. A pediatric neurologist checked me out and found nothing abnormal.
Doctor: Did they perform any additional tests, like magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), electromyography (EMG), somatosensory-evoked potentials (SEP) of the tibial nerve, electroencephalogram (EEG), or a lumbar puncture?
Patient: Yes, they did all of those tests, but they still didn't find any pathology.
Doctor: What about any gynecological examinations?
Patient: The gynecologist found multiple follicular cysts on my ovaries bilaterally but nothing that would explain my urinary retention.
Doctor: Our pediatric urologist performed an examination under general anesthesia. Have you been informed about the results?
Patient: They mentioned something about a free calibration of the urethra up to 26F and normal findings on cystoscopy.
Doctor: Yes, that's correct. The videourodynamic study (VUDS) showed an asensitive and hypotonic bladder. They had to stop the bladder filling at 360 mL due to your discomfort. The maximum intravesical pressure achieved was 11 cmH2O. Did you experience any discomfort when they pulled the urodynamic catheter out?
Patient: Yes, I felt some discomfort during that part of the procedure.
Doctor: Thank you for all the information. We will continue to monitor your condition and work on finding the cause of your urinary retention. In the meantime, please keep us updated on any changes in your symptoms.
gen_note:
**S: History of acute appendicitis, no recurrent UTIs or constipation.
**O: Patient reports decreased urinary frequency to twice per day with prolonged hesitancy.
**A: Patient's urinary stream is weak and slow initially, then becomes intermittent.
**P: Patient's symptoms improved after removal of indwelling Foley catheter.
**S: Patient underwent various tests, including urodynamic study, which revealed an asensitive bladder with low intravesical pressure.
ref_note:
S: The patient, who underwent an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy for non-perforated acute appendicitis two weeks ago, reports decreased urinary frequency (twice per day) with prolonged hesitancy, weak and interrupted micturition stream, and no improvement with straining. The patient denies previous history of urinary tract infections or constipation and reports daily bowel movements. Post-appendectomy, the patient experienced acute cystitis treated with antibiotics and required repeated catheterization due to inability to void, with urine volumes ranging from 300 to 1200 mL. The patient also reports loss of the urge to urinate and dull pain in the suprapubic region and right iliac fossa when the bladder is extremely distended.
O: Physical and ultrasound examinations at a tertiary center showed no obvious pathology. Neurological evaluations including MRI, EMG, SEP, EEG, and lumbar puncture revealed no abnormalities. Gynecological examination identified bilateral ovarian follicular cysts but no findings related to urinary retention. Pediatric urology assessment under general anesthesia showed free urethral calibration up to 26F and normal cystoscopy findings. Videourodynamic study indicated an asensitive and hypotonic bladder with maximum intravesical pressure of 11 cmH2O, and bladder filling was stopped at 360 mL due to discomfort.
A: The primary diagnosis is urinary retention with an asensitive and hypotonic bladder, post-surgical. Differential diagnoses could include neurogenic bladder, though current evaluations have not supported this. The presence of ovarian follicular cysts appears incidental and unrelated to the urinary symptoms.
P: Continue monitoring the patient's urinary function and symptoms. Plan for regular follow-up visits to reassess bladder function and response to any interventions. Consider consultation with a neurologist specializing in autonomic dysfunction given the lack of findings from standard neurological tests and the nature of bladder dysfunction. Educate the patient on recognizing signs of urinary tract infections and bladder distension. Discuss potential need for intermittent catheterization if spontaneous voiding does not improve. Encourage the patient to maintain adequate hydration and report any new symptoms or changes in urinary habits.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I'm a 45-year-old English teacher, and I've been suffering from right knee pain for about a year now. It got worse eight months ago.
Doctor: I see. Can you recall any trauma or injury that might have led to this pain?
Patient: No, I don't remember any specific trauma.
Doctor: What kind of treatment have you received so far?
Patient: I underwent conservative treatment at another clinic for six months. They prescribed intermittent non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs, some injections, but I don't know the exact drug, and physical therapy.
Doctor: Okay, how would you describe your pain and any other symptoms?
Patient: I have severe anterior knee pain when climbing stairs or squatting. Also, I've noticed a cystic mass in the posterior aspect of my knee joint that's been increasing in size.
Doctor: Let's perform a physical examination. *After examining* I found mild swelling and effusion in your right knee, but no localized heat sense. Painful crepitation and moderate tenderness are present during knee motion. There's also a large, non-tender cystic mass in the posterior aspect of the right knee joint. I noticed crepitation in your left knee too, but you mentioned no discomfort on the left side, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. No pain on the left side at all.
Doctor: I also observed that there's no cystic lesion on your left knee. Your right infrapatellar region is larger than normal and feels firm. Your passive full knee range of motion is possible, but painful. There's no tenderness on your tibial tubercle or patella.
Patient: Hmm, what do you think is causing this?
Doctor: I've reviewed your plain radiographic examination, and it shows a large ossicle beneath the patellar tendon and inside the infrapatellar fat pad in your right knee. Interestingly, there's a similar-sized ossicle in your left knee, partially fused to the hypertrophied tibial tuberosity.
Patient: What about the MRI results?
Doctor: Your right knee magnetic resonance images show a 3.8 x 1.3 x 3.0 cm sized, well-circumscribed ossicle. There are several smaller ossicles near the tibial tubercle as well. Inflammatory changes in synovium, infrapatellar fat pad, and patellar tendon are also visible. A reactive bone marrow edema was found at the anterior aspect of the tibial condyle.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: Based on your symptoms and test results, we'll discuss a treatment plan that may include medication, additional therapy, or even surgery if necessary. We will closely monitor your progress and make adjustments as needed. It's important to follow up regularly and report any changes in your symptoms.
Patient: Alright, thank you for your help, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll work together to get you back on your feet as soon as possible.
gen_note:
. We'll work together to get you back on your feet as soon as possible.
</dialogue>

**A: Differential diagnosis**

**P: Treatment plan**

- Treatment may include medication, physical therapy, or surgery.

The pain is described as severe, particularly when climbing stairs or squatting. The patient also notes a growing cystic mass in the posterior aspect of the right knee. No specific trauma is recalled. Previous treatments include intermittent NSAIDs, unspecified injections, and physical therapy.
O: Physical examination reveals mild swelling and effusion in the right knee, with no localized heat. There is painful crepitation and moderate tenderness during knee motion, and a large, non-tender cystic mass in the posterior aspect of the right knee. The patient's right infrapatellar region is enlarged and firm. Full passive knee range of motion is possible but painful. Radiographic examination shows a large ossicle beneath the patellar tendon and inside the infrapatellar fat pad of the right knee, with a similar ossicle partially fused in the left knee. MRI of the right knee reveals a 3.8 x 1.3 x 3.0 cm ossicle, smaller ossicles near the tibial tubercle, inflammatory changes in the synovium, infrapatellar fat pad, and patellar tendon, and reactive bone marrow edema at the anterior aspect of the tibial condyle.
A: The primary diagnosis is chronic right knee pain likely due to ossicle formation and associated inflammatory changes. Differential diagnoses may include other causes of chronic knee pain such as osteoarthritis or meniscal injury. The presence of a cystic mass and ossicles suggests a complex intra-articular pathology, possibly involving the synovium or infrapatellar fat pad.
P: The treatment plan will include a continuation of NSAIDs with careful monitoring for side effects, and consideration of corticosteroid injections for inflammation control. Referral to an orthopedic specialist is recommended for further evaluation regarding potential surgical intervention. Physical therapy will continue focusing on strengthening and range of motion exercises. Regular follow-up appointments will be scheduled to monitor progress and adjust treatment as necessary. The patient will be educated on the importance of reporting any new symptoms or changes in pain.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I'm experiencing sudden epigastric pain, and I feel like I'm in shock.
Doctor: I see. In that case, let me check your vital signs. We need to find out what's causing this shock. Have you had any recent medical issues?
Patient: Yes, I was hospitalized a month ago in your department and underwent a patch repair for a gastric ulcer perforation.
Doctor: Alright, let's perform a contrast-enhanced CT scan to get more information. 
(After CT scan)
Doctor: The CT scan revealed a retroperitoneal hematoma in your pancreatic head, aneurysm formation in the PDA, and extraluminal compression to the celiac trunk. Extravasation was also detected around the aneurysm in the PDA, but no liquid was retained in your peritoneal cavity.
Patient: Oh, that sounds serious. What should we do?
Doctor: We will perform an emergent IVR for hemostasis to address the retroperitoneal hemorrhage from the ruptured PDA aneurysm. Arteriography of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) will be done through a sheath introduced in your right femoral artery.
Patient: Okay, go ahead.
(After the procedure)
Doctor: The imaging of the SMA revealed the development of several collaterals in your pancreatic head, and the common and proper hepatic arteries were imaged via these collaterals. The aneurysm in your PDA had leakage of the contrast-enhanced agent with a diameter of 9.3 mm. We have completed the IVR hemostasis by performing PDA coil embolization.
Patient: So, what's next?
Doctor: We will conduct SMA arteriography to see the other collaterals perfusing your proper hepatic artery. After the IVR therapy, we will monitor your blood chemical analysis for several weeks to ensure that your transaminase level is not elevated and hepatic infarction is negative.
Patient: Got it. And what about the obstruction caused by the hematoma?
Doctor: We observed obstruction of the duodenal passage resulting from the hematoma for a few weeks. However, bypass surgery was not required as the obstruction was completely relieved as the hematoma was naturally and gradually absorbed.
Patient: That's a relief. What could have caused all this?
Doctor: In your case, collateral perfusion pathways from the SMA developed to compensate for the reduced CA blood flow due to MAL compression, and the aneurysm might have been generated in the PDA due to the abnormal changes in hemodynamic flow. Preservative treatment did not appear to relieve the CA compression. Additionally, we considered that new aneurysms may form following new collateral circulation after IVR hemostasis.
Patient: I see. Thank you for explaining everything, doctor. I'll make sure to follow up on my treatments and tests.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please make sure to attend your follow-up appointments, and don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. Take care!

No liquid retention in the peritoneal cavity was noted. Post-procedure imaging indicated a 9.3 mm aneurysm in the PDA with leakage of contrast agent. The prognosis depends on the effectiveness of the IVR hemostasis and the patient's response to ongoing monitoring.

The patient was advised to attend follow-up appointments and monitor for any new symptoms. Education on the importance of follow-up and adherence to treatment was provided.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi there, I understand you're a 13-year-old girl who has been experiencing abdominal pain and bloody stool. Can you tell me more about how long this has been happening and how it's been progressing?
Patient: Yeah, I started having abdominal pain about 3 months ago. At first, it wasn't too bad and would come and go, so I didn't see a doctor. But lately, the pain has gotten worse, and I've been having bloody stool more often.
Doctor: I see. We performed an imaging study and it showed that there's a mass, including a fecalith, occupying your pelvic and right lower abdominal cavity (Fig.). Based on this, we made a preoperative diagnosis of an acute appendicitis with an appendiceal mass (Fig.). We've already done drainage of the abscess and an appendectomy.
Patient: Oh, okay. So what did you find during the procedure?
Doctor: Although the body of your appendix looked intact, as well as your ileum and cecum, the histopathological examination revealed PAA in the tip of the resected appendix. Because of this, we have planned a radical operation for the residual tumor of PAA in your pelvic cavity.
Patient: What does that operation involve?
Doctor: It involves a whole mass resection and ileocecal resection with lymph node dissection. In the first operation, we speculate that we removed the body of your appendix but left most of the mass and the tip of the appendix. So in the second operation, we will remove the mass that was derived from the tip of your appendix.
Patient: Will you need to remove any other organs?
Doctor: Unfortunately, yes. The masses are tightly adherent with infiltration into your sigmoid colon, uterus, and right ovary. We will need to remove these organs, and then perform a subsequent sigmoid colostomy (Fig.). However, we will preserve your left ovary to maintain your fertility.
Patient: What were the results of the pathological examination?
Doctor: The pathological findings demonstrated negative margins and no lymph node invasions. Your final pathological stage is pT4(SI)N0M0, stage II based on TNM-7th edition 2009.
Patient: How was my recovery after the operation?
Doctor: Your postoperative course was uneventful, which is a good sign.
Patient: Did I receive any additional treatment after the operation?
Doctor: Yes, you received chemotherapy consisting of 6 cycles of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), leucovorin (LV), and oxaliplatin (mFOLFOX6), followed by 6 cycles of simplified LV and 5-FU (sLV5FU2).
Patient: How am I doing now?
Doctor: You're doing well on follow-up, and there has been no progression of your condition. We'll continue to monitor your health closely to ensure your ongoing well-being.

Pathological examination showed negative margins, no lymph node invasions, and a final stage of pT4(SI)N0M0, stage II. Postoperative recovery was uneventful. A: The primary diagnosis is pseudomyxoma appendicei (PAA) with complications including infiltration into adjacent organs necessitating extensive surgical intervention. The patient's condition is currently stable with no progression post-treatment.
P: The management plan includes ongoing close monitoring and follow-up to detect any signs of recurrence or complications. The patient will continue with regular medical reviews to assess her recovery and response to the chemotherapy. Further education on the signs of potential complications and lifestyle adjustments post-surgery will be provided to ensure optimal recovery and maintenance of health.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having some problems for the past two years. I noticed a hard lesion in my anal canal, but I haven't gotten it officially diagnosed or treated yet.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any other health issues during this time?
Patient: Yes, about ten months ago, I had a cholecystectomy due to cholelithiasis.
Doctor: Did the doctors find anything during the perioperative diagnostic examination?
Patient: They did. They found some suspicious lesions in my anal canal and some enlarged pelvic lymph nodes.
Doctor: What about your medical history? Do you have any comorbidities or a family history of malignancies?
Patient: I have gout, and my Karnofsky performance status is 90. I've never had radiotherapy, but I do have a second-degree family history of malignancies.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Let's discuss the results of your digital rectal examination. It identified mild prostatomegaly and a palpable suspicious nodule in the left prostate lobe. There were no signs of extracapsular extension. Additionally, a large ulcerated mass was found in the dorsal anal canal wall, but no lymphadenopathies in the inguinal region.
Patient: Oh, I see. What about the colonoscopy?
Doctor: The colonoscopy confirmed the presence of a suspicious lesion on the posterior anal canal, extending up to the anorectal junction.
Patient: And the MRI results?
Doctor: The magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed an infiltrative lesion of the anal canal with a maximum diameter of 3.2 cm, a high-grade suspicion of sphincter infiltration, and two enlarged lymphadenopathies in the mesorectum and right internal iliac region, both with a maximal diameter of 2 cm. These are suspicious of tumor metastases.
Patient: What about that area in the prostate?
Doctor: The MRI also found an area with a maximal diameter of 2 cm within the left prostate basis with restricted diffusion and a lower apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) than the surrounding healthy prostate tissue. It appeared hypointense on ADC maps but hyperintense on diffusion-weighted maps.
Patient: What did the biopsies show?
Doctor: The biopsies confirmed a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal and a moderately differentiated prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (3 + 4) in both lobes.
Patient: Is there anything else I should know?
Doctor: You tested negative for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), and your carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels were also assessed.
Patient: Thank you for explaining everything to me, Doctor.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I understand you have been monitored at a neurology clinic and were referred to our clinic due to sustained hemifacial pain on the right side. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct. The pain has been bothering me for a while now.
Doctor: I also noticed that you have been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2. Is it under control?
Patient: Yes, I've been managing it well.
Doctor: That's good to hear. I have reviewed your anterior rhinoscopic and endoscopic nasal examination results, and there were no pathological findings. However, your nasal septum is deviated to the left. Your hematological and biochemical parameters are normal, which is a good sign.
Patient: Oh, okay. So, what's causing the pain then?
Doctor: We performed a paranasal computed tomography (PNCT) imaging, and it revealed concha bullosa variation of the bilateral middle turbinates, and soft tissue density in the right concha bullosa. We then incised the concha bullosa by applying topical anesthesia to your right nasal cavity and performed a punch biopsy.
Patient: Hmm, and what did the pathology report say?
Doctor: The pathology report concluded that there were fungal hyphae and necrobiotic material. So, we prepared you for surgery. After receiving your written consent, we planned an endoscopic sinus surgery under general anesthesia.
Patient: I remember that. How did the surgery go?
Doctor: The surgery went well. We excised the lateral and inferior lamellae of the concha bullosa and submitted the infected material inside for pathologic examination. We controlled the bleeding, and the intervention was finalized.
Patient: That's a relief. What was my post-operative treatment?
Doctor: We prescribed a nasal wash and anti-inflammatory treatment for you. The pathological examination report revealed fungal organisms and their hyphae in the necrobiotic material. An advanced microbiological examination cultured "Aspergillus oryzae" through sequential analysis of the ribosomal DNA genes in the aspirated material.
Patient: So, how am I doing now?
Doctor: During your post-operative 6-month follow-up, we observed that your headache complaints were diminished and your nasal passage was open. It seems like the surgery and treatment have been successful.
Patient: That's great to hear! Thank you so much, doctor.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: Actually, I don't have any significant past medical history.
Doctor: Alright. Can you tell me what happened prior to your admission here?
Patient: I'm not sure. I just moved from Puerto Rico three weeks ago, and then I was found unresponsive at home with foamy secretions around my mouth.
Doctor: I see. You were found apneic and pulseless, so the paramedics performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) on you. After prolonged CPR, you had the return of spontaneous circulation and were admitted to the ICU. We started you on therapeutic hypothermia as well.
Patient: Oh, okay.
Doctor: Your urine toxicology showed the presence of cocaine, benzodiazepines, and cannabinoids. The most likely cause of your cardiac arrest was thought to be an overdose.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We also initiated antibiotics, vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam, along with vasopressors for septic shock. You were put on mechanical ventilation and intubation for respiratory failure. We have been closely monitoring your laboratory studies.
Patient: Okay, and what happened next?
Doctor: When we discontinued propofol, you remained unresponsive but showed muscle twitching. We performed an Electroencephalogram (EEG) which showed encephalopathy without seizure activity.
Patient: Hmm, that's concerning.
Doctor: On day three, you had repeated episodes of twitching, decerebrate posturing, and eyes rolling, so we restarted propofol. A repeat EEG showed similar results to the prior one. We also did a Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your brain, which showed diffuse injury and restricted diffusion involving both basal ganglia, bilateral frontal, and occipital cortices.
Patient: That sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it is. You continued to have repeated episodes of decerebrate posturing, rhythmic jaw movements, sweating, fever, and tachycardia. Ultimately, we had to perform a tracheostomy and gastrostomy tube placement.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: After a week of initial antibiotic treatment, your sputum cultures grew Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which resolved with a course of gentamicin nebulizers.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: We consulted infectious disease specialists for your repeated fevers. Your blood cultures, sputum cultures, and urine Legionella antigen came back negative.
Patient: So, what could be causing the fevers?
Doctor: We did a urinalysis for infection, checked for decubitus ulcers and rashes, but nothing was identified. Thyroid function tests (TFT) ruled out hyperthyroidism, and an ultrasound of your abdomen showed no signs of acalculous cholecystitis. We also tested you for Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, and performed an interferon-gamma release assay, all of which came back negative.
Patient: I see. What's the plan moving forward?
Doctor: We will continue monitoring your condition closely and provide appropriate treatments as needed. We will also discuss any further steps and follow-up requirements with you and your family.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help.
gen_note:
**S: History of present illness**
- Patient is a 35-year-old male with no significant past medical history.

**O: Past medical history**
- No significant past medical history.

**A: Past medical events**
- Found unresponsive and pulseless at home 3 weeks ago.
- Received CPR and was admitted to the ICU.
- Started on therapeutic hypothermia.

**P: Current medical condition**
- Patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.
- EEG showed encephalopathy without seizure activity.
- Repeated episodes of decerebrate posturing, rhythmic jaw movements, and eyes rolling.
- Patient developed Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection in sputum cultures.
ref_note:
S: The patient, recently moved from Puerto Rico, was found unresponsive at home with foamy secretions around the mouth. The patient has no significant past medical history. The patient reported being unaware of the events leading to hospitalization but was informed about the use of cocaine, benzodiazepines, and cannabinoids prior to the incident.
O: Upon admission, the patient was apneic, pulseless, and underwent prolonged CPR with return of spontaneous circulation. Therapeutic hypothermia was initiated. Urine toxicology was positive for cocaine, benzodiazepines, and cannabinoids. The patient was treated with vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and vasopressors for septic shock, and required mechanical ventilation and intubation. EEG showed encephalopathy without seizure activity. MRI of the brain indicated diffuse injury with restricted diffusion in both basal ganglia, bilateral frontal, and occipital cortices. Sputum cultures grew Pseudomonas aeruginosa, treated with gentamicin nebulizers. Blood cultures, sputum cultures, urine Legionella antigen, TFT, and abdominal ultrasound were negative for other sources of infection.
A: The primary diagnosis is hypoxic-ischemic brain injury secondary to cardiac arrest, likely due to polydrug overdose. Differential diagnoses included septic shock and encephalopathy. The patient shows signs of severe neurological damage and ongoing complications from the initial event and subsequent treatments.
P: Continue intensive monitoring and supportive care in the ICU. Maintain mechanical ventilation, vasopressor support, and antibiotic therapy as indicated. Regularly reassess neurological status and adjust sedation to manage symptoms of decerebrate posturing and other involuntary movements. Engage infectious disease specialists for ongoing fevers and potential infections. Discuss long-term care options with the patient's family, considering the severity of brain injury and potential for prolonged recovery or permanent disability.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having some right-sided chest pain lately.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your medical history?
Patient: Well, I've been diabetic for about 4 years now and I'm also hypertensive. I've been on treatment for both.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Do you have any other medical concerns or history?
Patient: Yeah, I've had primary amenorrhoea, but it was never investigated before.
Doctor: Okay. Let's do a physical examination. Please step on the scale and measure your height.
Patient: Alright, I weigh 58 kg and I'm 155 cm tall.
Doctor: Thank you. Now let me check your blood pressure and examine your secondary sexual characteristics.
Patient: Okay, sure.
Doctor: Your blood pressure seems to be normal, and your secondary sexual characteristics are also normal. Now, I'm going to listen to your breathing. Please take deep breaths for me.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: Hmm, I noticed that there are absent breath sounds on the right side of your chest, and it appears there is a mediastinal shift to the right as well.
Patient: What does that mean, doc?
Doctor: The absence of breath sounds on the right side of your chest could indicate a problem with your lungs, and the mediastinal shift to the right may be related to that issue. We need to investigate this further and find out the cause of your chest pain. I recommend scheduling some tests as soon as possible.
Patient: Oh, okay. What tests do you recommend?
Doctor: We'll start with a chest X-ray and some blood tests to get a better understanding of the underlying cause. Based on the results, we may need to perform additional tests or start treatment.
Patient: I understand. I'll schedule the tests as soon as I can.
Doctor: That's great. Please keep me updated on the results, and don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions or if your symptoms worsen.
Patient: Will do, doc. Thanks for your help.
Doctor: You're welcome, and take care.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you've presented to the ophthalmology clinic today with a complaint of acute onset right eye pain with extra-ocular movement. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having right eye periorbital swelling, redness, and my upper right lid is drooping. I've also been experiencing bilateral tearing.
Doctor: I understand. When did these symptoms start?
Patient: They began about 24 hours ago, right after I received my first zoledronic acid infusion for osteoporosis.
Doctor: Thank you for that information. Based on your past medical history, I see that you have chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, Sjogren's syndrome, and systemic lupus erythematosus. You've been on cyclosporine 75 mg daily and monthly belimumab 120 mg/1.5 ml for your rheumatologic conditions for 3 years prior to this presentation, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Let's discuss your ophthalmic exam results. Your best-corrected visual acuity was 20/25–2 in the right eye and 20/25–3 in the left eye. Intraocular pressure was 14 mmHg in the right eye and 13 mmHg in the left eye. The external exam of your right eye showed mild upper lid edema, erythema, ptosis, and a -1 adduction defect. Do you know what a slit lamp examination is?
Patient: I'm not sure, can you explain?
Doctor: Sure, a slit lamp examination allows us to take a closer look at the structures of your eye. In your case, we found conjunctival chemosis, which is swelling of the eye's outer surface, but no issues with the anterior chamber or any flare. Additionally, the posterior segment exam showed that you have posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) in both eyes.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We also attempted 24–2 visual field testing, but it wasn't reliable due to frequent fixation loss caused by your eye pain. Based on your symptoms and history, we ordered a contrast-enhanced MRI which showed ill-defined right orbital soft tissue thickening and enhancement in the retro-orbital intraconal space with extension along the retro-orbital scleral contour and surrounding the anterior optic nerve sheath.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: Considering your rheumatologic history, we initially thought it could be orbital inflammation secondary to your lupus. However, based on the clinical presentation, MRI findings, and the timing of your symptoms in relation to your zoledronic acid infusion, we suspect that your orbital inflammation might be secondary to bisphosphonate therapy.
Patient: Oh, okay. So, what do we do now?
Doctor: We will start you on oral medications to manage the inflammation and monitor your symptoms closely. We will also keep in touch with your rheumatologist to ensure the best course of action for your treatment. If your symptoms worsen or do not improve, please return to the clinic immediately.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
gen_note:

Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate your help.
</dialogue>

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented with gradual onset of painless lower limb weakness, paresthesias, and increased urinary frequency for one week. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I've been feeling weak in my legs for the past week, and I've been experiencing some tingling sensations too. I've also noticed that I need to go to the bathroom more frequently.
Doctor: I see. Have you had any recent symptoms of infections, trauma, or accidents?
Patient: No, I haven't had any of those.
Doctor: Okay, let's discuss your past medical history. Do you have any family history of significant concern?
Patient: No, my family history is clear.
Doctor: Are you a non-smoker and teetotaler? And have you been exposed to any environmental factors such as industrial chemicals, radiation, heavy metals, or any toxin exposures?
Patient: Yes, I am a non-smoker and teetotaler. I haven't been exposed to any harmful substances like that.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Moving on, you mentioned that you lead an active life and used to live with your partner. Your Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status was 1 before admission. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: On your examination, we found symmetrical lower limb motor weakness in an upper motor neuron pattern with Medical Research Council (MRC) muscle power 4/5 both proximally and distally. We also observed reduced sensations in your lower limbs symmetrically to fine touch, pinprick, temperature, and proprioception, which progressed to significant sensory loss over the next couple of weeks. Your sensory level is slightly below the umbilicus at T11. However, there was no spinal tenderness. Do you have any questions so far?
Patient: No, I understand. Thank you for explaining.
Doctor: Additionally, your deep tendon reflexes in lower limbs were exaggerated with extensor plantar responses. The rest of your general and systemic examination was unremarkable. We conducted blood tests, including full blood count, inflammatory markers, B12, folate, thyroid functions, calcium, liver function test, and myeloma screen, which all came back normal. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis on the second day after admission was also normal with normal protein, glucose, and cytology, etc. Have you had any concerns about these tests?
Patient: No, I'm glad everything was normal.
Doctor: Finally, we evaluated you with a non-contrast MRI spine, which showed focal myelopathic cord signal at the conus and at the level of T10 and T11 vertebrae. The radiological differential diagnosis on MRI includes B12 deficiency, inflammatory, or infection-related causes. We will continue to investigate and monitor your condition closely. It's important that you follow up with us as needed and adhere to any recommendations we provide. Do you have any questions or concerns?
Patient: No, I appreciate all the information. I'll be sure to follow your recommendations. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll continue to work together to manage your symptoms and find the best course of treatment for you. Take care, and please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns.

**O: Patient has no recent symptoms of infections, trauma, or accidents.
**A: Patient has a history of active lifestyle and normal ECOG performance.

The patient denies any recent infections, trauma, or significant family medical history. The patient is a non-smoker and teetotaler with no exposure to harmful environmental factors. Previously, the patient had an ECOG performance status of 1.
O: Physical examination revealed symmetrical lower limb motor weakness in an upper motor neuron pattern with MRC muscle power 4/5 both proximally and distally. Sensory examination showed reduced sensations to fine touch, pinprick, temperature, and proprioception with a sensory level at T11. Deep tendon reflexes in lower limbs were exaggerated with extensor plantar responses. Blood tests including full blood count, inflammatory markers, B12, folate, thyroid functions, calcium, liver function test, and myeloma screen were normal. CSF analysis was normal. MRI of the spine showed focal myelopathic cord signal at the conus and at the level of T10 and T11 vertebrae.
A: The primary diagnosis is a spinal cord pathology likely due to myelopathy, with differential diagnoses including B12 deficiency, inflammatory, or infection-related causes. The MRI findings and clinical presentation support this assessment.
P: The patient will continue to be monitored closely with follow-up appointments to assess progression or improvement of symptoms. Further investigations may be required to narrow down the specific cause of the myelopathy. The patient is advised to adhere to follow-up schedules and report any new symptoms or concerns. Referral to a neurologist for specialized care may be considered if symptoms persist or worsen.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello Mr. A, I understand you've been brought in by your family due to agitation, aggression, and a recent verbal altercation with your neighbors. Can you tell me more about what happened?
Patient: Yeah, doc. I don't know what came over me. I just got really angry and started arguing with everyone around me.
Doctor: I see. It's important for me to know your background. I understand you're a 26-year-old immigrant from Afghanistan, living with your mother and sister?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Your family mentioned you have a history of polysubstance use, including cannabis, nicotine, and alcohol. Is that accurate?
Patient: Yeah, I've used those substances before.
Doctor: When you came into the emergency room, you seemed agitated and unresponsive to verbal redirection. Were you under the influence of any substances at that time?
Patient: I had smoked an unknown amount of marijuana and took one pill of ecstasy about 12-15 hours earlier.
Doctor: Your family reported that they had never seen you in such a state before. Your sister mentioned that prior to the ER visit, you displayed uncontrollable aggression and even damaged furniture at home. Can you recall what triggered this behavior?
Patient: I don't know, doc. I just got really angry and lost control.
Doctor: Your sister also mentioned that you left home early in the morning in a fit of rage and she found you later banging on the glass windows of a pharmacy with a book. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yeah, I was so angry and confused.
Doctor: It seems you experienced an episode of psychosis with a fixation on a recently read fictitious character, leading to suicidal ideation. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: I don't know why, but I became obsessed with this character and started thinking about ending my life.
Doctor: Your sister provided more details about your past trauma. You lived with an alcohol-dependent father and were a victim of racial abuse and physical assault. This has led to posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and a protectionist savior complex. Does that sound accurate?
Patient: Yeah, that's true. I've been through a lot.
Doctor: When you were in the ER, you refused to provide blood and urine samples for toxicology screening. Is there a reason why?
Patient: I just didn't want to do it at that time. I was too agitated.
Doctor: I understand. It's important for us to properly evaluate your condition and provide the appropriate care. Can we proceed with the toxicology screening now?
Patient: Yeah, sure. I'm more calm now.
Doctor: Thank you, Mr. A. We'll proceed with the screening and discuss the results with you once they're available. In the meantime, we'll continue to monitor your condition and provide support for your mental health.

</dialogue>

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having some difficulty breathing and mild chest pressure for about a week now. It reminds me of the symptoms I had when I had a pulmonary embolism more than 10 years ago.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: Yes, I have a history of peripartum cardiomyopathy, mitral regurgitation, and hypertension.
Doctor: Thank you for sharing that. Were you referred to the emergency department due to your severely elevated blood pressure?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Have you been taking any medications to manage your hypertension?
Patient: I was prescribed hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ), but I stopped taking it three days ago because it was causing increased urinary frequency. I've been maintaining compliance with losartan, though.
Doctor: Okay, let's go over your vital signs at presentation. Your temperature was 37.2 °C, BP was 218/150, heart rate 121, respiratory rate 16, and pulse oximetry was 100% on room air. Upon examination, your lungs were clear to auscultation, and you had no S3, jugular vein distention, or lower extremity edema. The remainder of your physical exam was unremarkable.
Patient: Hmm, I see.
Doctor: We also conducted some further tests, including labs, an electrocardiogram (EKG), a chest radiograph, and a bedside echocardiogram (BSE) performed by ultrasound trained EPs. Your initial troponin levels were mildly elevated at 0.08 µg/L, but they down-trended to 0.05 µg/L.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: Mildly elevated troponin levels could indicate some stress on your heart, but it's a good sign that they are decreasing. Your chest x-ray showed mild cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vasculature. Additionally, your EKG revealed a new left bundle branch block (LBBB).
Patient: And what about the echocardiogram?
Doctor: During your initial BSE, your blood pressure was 252/163, with a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 170, and your peak longitudinal strain (PLS) was -3.5%. The ejection fraction (EF) was not calculated, but it was estimated to be mildly reduced. Six hours later, your blood pressure improved to 171/94 (MAP = 123), and we performed a repeat BSE with a recalculated PLS.
Patient: So, what's the next step, doc?
Doctor: We'll closely monitor your blood pressure, heart function, and strain. It's important for you to continue taking your losartan and discuss with your primary care doctor about potentially restarting hydrochlorothiazide or considering alternative medications to manage your hypertension. Regular follow-up appointments and monitoring of your symptoms will be necessary to ensure your condition remains stable.
Patient: Alright, thank you for the information and guidance.
Doctor: You're welcome. Make sure to reach out if you have any further concerns or if your symptoms worsen. Take care.
gen_note:

dialogue:
Doctor: Good morning, Mr. Tanaka. I see from your medical history that you have hypertension, dyslipidemia, and peripheral vascular disease. Can you tell me about any symptoms you're experiencing?
Patient: Good morning, Doctor. I've been experiencing some chest discomfort and shortness of breath lately.
Doctor: I understand. When you were 71, you had a successful endovascular treatment for your occlusive right common iliac artery. At that time, we performed transthoracic echocardiography for screening, which revealed a dilated aortic root with a width of 49 mm. Do you remember that?
Patient: Yes, I remember.
Doctor: We also did an electrocardiogram-gated cardiac computed tomography (EG-CT) that revealed two sinus of Valsalva aneurysms (SVAs) in both the left and right coronary sinuses, with no obstruction to surrounding cardiac structures. The sizes of the SVAs were 27.2 mm and 33.1 mm for the left and right sides, respectively. Due to their relatively small size, we decided to observe them carefully for 5 years. 
Patient: Right, I've been coming in for regular check-ups.
Doctor: I appreciate your diligence. In your recent follow-up EG-CT, we noticed that the sizes of the SVAs had grown to 34.5 mm and 35.7 mm, respectively. The transthoracic echocardiography also showed moderate aortic regurgitation. The SVA in the left coronary sinus has grown between the pulmonary artery and the left atrium, bulging out on the anterior surface of the heart. The SVA in the right coronary sinus has also grown, pressing the right ventricular outflow tract.
Patient: That doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We concluded that both SVAs are extracardiac, meaning they're expanding on the surface of the heart. This type has a relatively high risk of rupture, which could be life-threatening. Given this situation, I recommend that you undergo surgery for SVA removal. 
Patient: I see. What does the surgery involve?
Doctor: The operation will be performed via median sternotomy with cardiopulmonary bypass. After inducing cardioplegic arrest, we will transect the ascending aorta just above the sinotubular junction. Upon inspecting the interior of the aortic root, we will remove the SVAs and repair the affected areas. 
Patient: I understand. I'm willing to provide my informed consent for the surgery.
Doctor: Thank you for your trust in us, Mr. Tanaka. We will do our best to ensure a successful surgery and follow-up care.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, I see that you've presented to the emergency room with a complaint of a severe headache for 1 day. Can you tell me more about your headache?
Patient: Yes, it's been a throbbing headache with photophobia, and I've had multiple episodes of nonbloody vomiting.
Doctor: I see. You've reported a history of closed head trauma and intermittent rhinorrhea, especially when leaning forward, which resolved a few months prior to this presentation. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: You also mentioned a history of intermittent migraines and coronary artery disease. Is there anything else I should be aware of?
Patient: No, I think that's everything.
Doctor: Okay, let's discuss your physical examination. You had photophobia, but no nuchal rigidity or focal motor or sensory neurological deficits were found. Your vital signs were also unremarkable. We did some laboratory tests and found that your hemoglobin was 11.6 g/dl, your white cell count (WBC) was 13.1 × 10^9/1 with 84.7% neutrophils, serum sodium was 138 mEq/l, potassium was 4.1 mEq/l, and creatinine was 0.7 mg/dl. All your liver function tests were within normal limits.
Patient: Okay, that's good to know.
Doctor: We admitted you to the medical floor and performed a lumbar puncture. The opening pressure was 35 cm H2O, and the CSF fluid analysis showed a WBC of 1850 cells/uL with 70% segmental, red blood cells at 5, protein at 175 mg/dl which is higher than the normal range of 15-45 mg/dl, and glucose at 40 mg/dl which is within the normal range of 40-70 mg/dl. The cryptococcal CSF antigen was detected with a titer of 1 : 1024, which is higher than the normal range of < 1 : 2 titer. Your bacterial antigen was negative, and there was no growth on bacterial CSF culture.
Patient: Oh, I see.
Doctor: We also checked your HIV serology, which came back negative, confirmed by nondetectable HIV RNA and an absolute CD4 count of 1168.
Patient: That's a relief.
Doctor: Given your history and suspicion for a traumatic CSF leak, we did a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of your head and sinus, but they were both unrevealing. Due to the low sensitivity of a regular MRI in diagnosing CSF leaks, we performed a computed tomography (CT) cisternogram.
Patient: And what did that show?
Doctor: The CT cisternogram revealed evidence of leakage of intrathecally injected contrast, confirming a CSF leak.
Patient: So what does that mean for me, doctor?
Doctor: It means that we have identified the cause of your symptoms, and we will now work on a treatment plan to address the CSF leak and manage your headaches. We'll monitor your progress closely and adjust the plan as needed.
Patient: Alright, thank you, doctor.
gen_note:
</dialogue>

The patient has a history of closed head trauma and intermittent rhinorrhea, which resolved a few months prior.
O: Physical examination showed photophobia but no nuchal rigidity or focal neurological deficits. Vital signs were unremarkable. Laboratory tests revealed hemoglobin at 11.6 g/dl, WBC at 13.1 × 10^9/l with 84.7% neutrophils, serum sodium at 138 mEq/l, potassium at 4.1 mEq/l, and creatinine at 0.7 mg/dl. Liver function tests were normal. Lumbar puncture indicated an opening pressure of 35 cm H2O, CSF analysis showed elevated protein at 175 mg/dl, normal glucose at 40 mg/dl, and a high cryptococcal CSF antigen titer at 1 : 1024. HIV serology was negative. MRI of the head and sinus were unrevealing. A CT cisternogram confirmed a CSF leak.
A: The primary diagnosis is a CSF leak secondary to a possible traumatic etiology, evidenced by the history and confirmed by CT cisternogram. The elevated CSF protein and presence of cryptococcal antigen suggest an infectious or inflammatory process, possibly cryptococcal meningitis, which needs to be addressed alongside the CSF leak.
P: The management plan includes initiating appropriate antifungal therapy for cryptococcal meningitis, considering the patient's elevated cryptococcal antigen titer. The CSF leak will be managed with measures to reduce CSF pressure and surgical consultation for possible repair. The patient will be monitored closely for signs of increased intracranial pressure and other complications. Education will be provided regarding the signs of meningitis and the importance of adhering to the treatment regimen. Follow-up appointments will be scheduled to assess progress and adjust the treatment plan as necessary.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you've presented to our pancreas multidisciplinary clinic. What seems to be the issue?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. For the past 2 months, I've been experiencing some generalized bloating and epigastric discomfort.
Doctor: I see. In that case, we should perform a computed tomography (CT) scan to get a better look at what might be causing your symptoms. 
(After the CT scan)
Doctor: Your CT scan results have come back, and they demonstrated an 11.2 × 9.6 cm heterogeneous solid appearing mass in the tail of your pancreas. The mass has several small peripheral calcifications and lobulated contours abutting your spleen, stomach, and splenic flexure of colon. However, there doesn't seem to be any direct invasion.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good. What do we do now?
Doctor: We will need to perform a distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy with splenic artery lymph node dissection to remove the mass.
(After the surgery)
Doctor: The surgery went well. Intraoperatively, we observed a large soft lobular cystic mass at the pancreatic tail. The mass was locally contained without any obvious invasion of surrounding structures or gross metastasis. We sent it for histopathological assessment.
Patient: What were the results of the assessment?
Doctor: The assessment established it as a pT3pN0pMx SPNP (CD56pos nuclear β-cateninpos chromograninneg and synaptophysinneg). Margins were negative, and there was no lymphovascular or perineural invasion. You'll be discharged home after a period of convalescence in the hospital.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor.
(Four years later)
Doctor: I see you've been referred back to our clinic after a biopsy-proven recurrence in the splenic fossa. We will need to perform additional surgery to remove the tumor.
Patient: What will the surgery involve?
Doctor: We'll need to perform a wedge gastrectomy and partial colectomy to resect the tumor, as it is densely adherent to the splenic flexure and gastric fundus. Additionally, we'll remove a 4 cm nodule of tumor adherent to the diaphragm and omentum.
(After the surgery)
Doctor: The surgery was successful, but the tumor was soft, extremely friable, and fractured with minimal manipulation. It remained densely adherent to the left diaphragm, left kidney, and left adrenal gland. We were able to dissect down through the Gerota's fat and strip the anterior capsule of the kidney clean to remove the tumor from the kidney and adrenal gland. We also removed the other end of the mass, which was adherent to the diaphragm, along with a portion of the diaphragm.
Patient: What does the pathology report say?
Doctor: The final pathology report confirmed the presence of recurrent metastatic SPNP in your omentum, diaphragm, and accessory spleen. We'll continue to monitor your condition closely.
Patient: Thank you for your help, Doctor.
gen_note:

Patient: Thank you for your help, Doctor.
</dialogue>

Four years later, the patient presented with a biopsy-proven recurrence in the splenic fossa, experiencing no specific new symptoms mentioned.

Ongoing close monitoring and follow-up are planned to manage and detect further recurrence or metastasis. Further treatment options may include chemotherapy or radiation therapy depending on future assessments.

dialogue:
Doctor: Good morning, I see that you're here today to discuss your current psychiatric condition. Can you tell me about the symptoms you've been experiencing?
Patient: Yeah, well, I've had these obsessive thoughts and compulsive avoidance acts since I was 14. But back then, I knew they were just a product of my own mind, and I could live a mostly normal life.
Doctor: I understand that there was a sudden exacerbation of your symptoms in May 2016 when you were 19. What happened around that time?
Patient: After my final exams in high school, I tried cannabis five times, and then my symptoms got worse. I started having more severe obsessive thoughts, like I could hurt someone or even myself, and I had these involuntary obscene thoughts.
Doctor: Did you continue to recognize that these thoughts were a product of your own mind?
Patient: Yes, I fought those thoughts and continued to recognize their origin. But I also started experiencing hallucinations, like hearing voices and seeing optical distortions, like the shape of leaves appearing weird.
Doctor: It sounds like you've been dealing with a complex psychiatric syndrome, including obsessive-compulsive, schizophreniform, and derealization phenotypes. Have you experienced any other symptoms, such as anxiety or agitation?
Patient: Yeah, I developed diffuse anxiety and agitation, and I've had extreme dizziness, as if I've drunk five beers.
Doctor: I see. Have you been feeling down or having any suicidal thoughts?
Patient: Yes, I've had a depressed mood and suicidal ideation. I've also been having difficulty falling asleep and reduced energy levels, especially in the morning.
Doctor: Due to the severity of these symptoms, I understand that you were hospitalized at age 19. You received pharmacological treatment with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors for the obsessive-compulsive symptoms, such as citalopram up to 40 mg/day. How did that work for you?
Patient: It helped a bit, but not entirely.
Doctor: You also received neuroleptics for the schizophreniform symptoms, like olanzapine up to 20 mg/day, risperidone up to 5 mg/day, and aripiprazole up to 7.5 mg/day. However, I see that higher doses led to an increase in inner restlessness. Is that correct?
Patient: Yeah, that's right.
Doctor: Lastly, you were prescribed carbamazepine for neuronal network stabilization up to 500 mg. How has that been working for you?
Patient: It's been helpful, but I'm still struggling with some symptoms.
Doctor: I understand. It's important that we continue to monitor and adjust your treatment plan as needed to help manage your complex psychiatric syndrome. Please schedule regular follow-up appointments, and don't hesitate to contact us if you experience any significant changes in your symptoms or side effects from your medications.

Symptoms include severe obsessive thoughts, potential for self-harm, involuntary obscene thoughts, hallucinations (auditory and visual), diffuse anxiety, agitation, extreme dizziness, depressed mood, suicidal ideation, insomnia, and reduced morning energy. Previous treatments include SSRIs, neuroleptics, and carbamazepine, with partial improvement.

Medications have included citalopram up to 40 mg/day, olanzapine up to 20 mg/day, risperidone up to 5 mg/day, aripiprazole up to 7.5 mg/day, and carbamazepine up to 500 mg/day. Higher doses of neuroleptics increased inner restlessness.
A: The primary diagnosis is a complex psychiatric syndrome with elements of obsessive-compulsive disorder, schizophreniform disorder, and derealization. Differential diagnoses could include major depressive disorder and substance-induced psychotic disorder. The prognosis is cautious given the chronic nature and partial response to treatment.
P: Continue current pharmacotherapy while closely monitoring for efficacy and side effects. Adjust medications as necessary based on symptomatology and side effects. Schedule regular psychiatric follow-ups to reassess the treatment plan. Encourage cognitive-behavioral therapy to address obsessive-compulsive and depressive symptoms. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and the potential impact of substance use on psychiatric symptoms. Consider referral to a substance abuse specialist if needed.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see that you're a 30-year-old female with a history of intermittent jaundice for the last six years. Can you tell me more about when this jaundice occurs and how it affects you?
Patient: Hi, doctor. Yes, I've had episodes of jaundice during each of my pregnancies. I'm fourth gravida, with one live issue after a fourth-degree consanguineous marriage. The jaundice usually starts in the late second trimester and subsides slowly over two to three months after delivery. Between pregnancies, I have minimal or no jaundice.
Doctor: I see. And during these years, have you experienced any other symptoms, such as fever, pruritus, malaise, or abdominal pain?
Patient: No, doctor. I've been mostly asymptomatic, except for the jaundice. I don't have a history of fever, pruritus, malaise, or abdominal pain. I'm also a non-alcoholic and a non-smoker.
Doctor: That's helpful information. Do you have any history of blood transfusion, intravenous drug abuse, chronic drug intake, or exposure to occupational hazards?
Patient: No, I don't have any history of those things.
Doctor: Thank you for providing this information. Now, regarding your bilirubin levels, your pre-pregnancy levels were in the range of 3.0-4.0 mg/dL, which is higher than the normal value of 0.1-1.2 mg/dL. During the second trimester of each pregnancy, these levels would rise to about 11.0-12.0 mg/dL. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: It appears that you typically have isolated conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, with conjugated bilirubin levels rising to as high as 8.0 to 10.0 mg/dL, while unconjugated bilirubin remains in the range of 2.0-3.0 mg/dL. Your liver function test has always been normal, with serum transaminase levels less than 20 IU/L and serum bile acid levels and proteins within the normal range. Is that accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Given the absence of pruritus and normal bile acid levels and serum transaminases, we can exclude the diagnosis of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy. Additionally, there is no associated gestational hypertension or proteinuria. Your hemogram is unremarkable, and your peripheral smear has never shown any evidence of hemolysis. Therefore, thrombotic microangiopathies have also been ruled out. Have you ever had an ultrasound of your abdomen?
Patient: Yes, I had an ultrasound, and it showed a normal liver span and echotexture.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Lastly, have you been tested for viral markers related to hepatitis during your pregnancies?
Patient: Yes, I have, and the tests have always come back negative.
Doctor: Thank you for all this information. It seems that most common causes of jaundice during pregnancy have been ruled out. We will continue to monitor your bilirubin levels and liver function, and I will discuss your case with other specialists to determine the best course of action for your future pregnancies. Please make sure to schedule regular check-ups throughout your pregnancy and follow any further recommendations we may have.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hi, I heard you were referred to our clinic due to sudden visual loss in your right eye. Can you tell me more about what happened?
Patient: Yeah, it happened within 24 hours after a 2-hour airplane flight from Paris to Madrid. It was sudden and painless, but now I can't see well from my right eye.
Doctor: I see. Do you have any medical history we should be aware of?
Patient: I have well-controlled hypercholesterolemia.
Doctor: Alright. Let's check your vision. *After checking* Your best-corrected visual acuity is 20/200 in your right eye and 20/20 in your left eye. There is a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) in your right eye, as well as color vision deficiency and scotoma. 
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that there's an issue with the nerve response in your right eye, and you're having trouble with color and a blind spot in your vision. Now, let's do a funduscopic examination. *After the exam* I found swelling in your right optic disc, with superonasal flame-shaped hemorrhaging, venous congestion, and tortuosity. 
Patient: Is my left eye okay?
Doctor: Yes, your left eye appears normal, with a cup-to-disc ratio of less than 0.1, suggesting a "disc-at-risk." Let's perform a Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) for your right eye. *After FFA* There is late optic-disc staining in your right eye. 
Patient: What about other tests?
Doctor: We conducted cardiac and carotid Doppler ultrasound, autoimmune, and hypercoagulability tests. They were normal, except for slightly raised serum cholesterol levels. We also did a cranial computed tomography (CT) scan that revealed previously unknown white matter lesions. Based on these findings, you have been diagnosed with NA-AION associated with cerebral SVD.
Patient: What's the treatment for that?
Doctor: You will need to take aspirin 100 mg daily. *After one year* I understand you've developed visual disturbances in your left eye during a 10-day drive in the French Alps. Let's check your vision again. *After checking* Your BCVA is now 20/200 in your right eye and 20/40 in your left eye.
Patient: What's going on with my left eye now?
Doctor: Upon examination, there is edematous and flame-shaped retinal hemorrhaging at the border of the left ONH, vascular tortuosity, fluorescein leakage during FFA, and severe widespread visual field loss with central-sparing. This suggests a NA-AION in your left eye as well.
Patient: How is my vision now?
Doctor: At the time of publication, your best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) remains the same. We will continue to monitor your condition and adjust treatment as necessary.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. What brings you to the ER today?
Patient: Hi, Doctor. I fell and hurt my lower back. It's really painful.
Doctor: I see. Let's check your vital signs first. Your blood pressure is 159/91 mmHg, heart rate is 77 bpm, body temperature is 36.5°C, respiratory rate is 12/min, and your SpO2 is 100% on ambient air. Those numbers look mostly fine, but your blood pressure is a bit high. We'll keep an eye on that. Now, can you tell me more about your lumbago?
Patient: Well, it started right after I fell. It's a sharp pain in my lower back, and it's making it difficult to move around.
Doctor: I understand. We'll perform a Roentgenography and CT scan to get a better look at your lumbar area. Please wait for a moment while we get the results.
(After the tests)
Doctor: The results show that you have a compression fracture of your Th12 vertebra. The AIS score is 3, and your RTS is 7.8408, with a Ps of 0.99416.
Patient: Oh no, that sounds serious. What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the fracture is relatively stable, and the injury severity is moderate. Fortunately, conservative therapy is suitable for your condition. We'll provide you with a medical corset to help support your back during the healing process.
Patient: How long will it take for me to recover?
Doctor: You'll need to wear the corset for a few weeks, and you should avoid any heavy lifting or strenuous activities during that time. You'll be discharged on day 17 of your hospitalization. It's important to follow up with your primary care doctor to monitor your progress.
Patient: Okay, I understand. I'll be careful and follow your advice.
Doctor: That's great. With proper care and rest, you should fully recover from your injury in about 37 months.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I'm relieved to hear that I'll eventually get better.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns during your recovery, don't hesitate to reach out to your primary care doctor or come back to the ER. Take care and get well soon.
Patient: Thanks, Doctor. I appreciate your help.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, can you please tell me about your medical history?
Patient: I have insulin-dependent diabetes and I've had it for about 20 years now. I also have arterial hypertension.
Doctor: I see. What brings you to the emergency department today?
Patient: I've been experiencing abdominal symptoms for the past 2 months, like meteorism and bloating. I feel like my abdomen is enlarged.
Doctor: Do you have any other symptoms such as diarrhea, loss of appetite, weight loss, persistent fever, night sweats, headaches, anxiety, gastric ulcer disease, or skin rash?
Patient: No, I haven't experienced any of those symptoms.
Doctor: Have you ever had a neoplasm, pancreatitis, or gall bladder stones in the past? And have you undergone an abdominal examination before?
Patient: I don't recall ever having a neoplasm or suffering from pancreatitis or gall bladder stones. And no, I haven't had an abdominal examination before.
Doctor: Okay, I understand that you had a computed tomography (CT) scan a few days ago which showed a tumor in the pancreatic head, and you were referred to our clinic. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Can you tell me more about your diabetes treatment? You mentioned you've had diabetes for 20 years.
Patient: I was initially treated with orally administered anti-diabetic drugs for more than 12 years. Now, I'm using insulin glargine as my treatment.
Doctor: And you're also taking medications for your arterial hypertension, right?
Patient: Yes, I'm taking two different anti-hypertensives, two diuretics, and acetylsalicylic acid.
Doctor: Do you have any allergies?
Patient: Yes, I have an allergy to metformin.
Doctor: Do you smoke tobacco or drink alcohol?
Patient: No, I don't smoke or drink alcohol.
Doctor: During your physical examination, you were found to be conscious and oriented, in fair general condition, and in a good nutritional state. Your heart and lung examinations were normal, and your abdomen was soft and non-tender without any palpable masses. Icterus and lymphadenopathy were also absent, and your vital signs were normal. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Your routine laboratory analysis showed some abnormal values. Your hemoglobin is 12.5 g/dl, hematocrit is 25%, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is 78 fl, and creatinine is 1.8 mg/dl. We'll need to further investigate these results and the tumor found in your pancreatic head to determine the best course of action. Please follow up with your primary care physician and schedule any necessary appointments.
Patient: Okay, thank you for the information, Doctor. I'll make sure to follow up with my primary care physician.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, what brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, I've been having complaints of massive abdominal distention and respiratory distress lately.
Doctor: I see. Let me take a look at your past medical history. It says here that you have a history of secondary infertility for four years and have one child aged eight years. You were also a candidate for In Vitro Fertilization (IVF) protocol due to tubal factors. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: During your first cycle of ovarian stimulation, you were prescribed metformin and Gonal-f 75 IU for six days and then continued for two days. Unfortunately, the cycle was cancelled due to a poor response after the second month. It was then that you started to suffer from gradual abdominal distention, is that right?
Patient: Yes, that's when it started.
Doctor: After that, you were under outpatient care and supportive treatment with a possible diagnosis of hyperstimulation syndrome. They prescribed antagonist GnRH for two days. At your next delayed month visit, they considered the probability of hyperthyroidism and you received gonadotropin hormone agonist (Decapeptyl). However, you were re-evaluated due to being unresponsive to treatment within this period. Is that all correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: It seems that trans-abdominal and transvaginal ultrasonography were performed and showed multiple multiloculated cystic masses with predominantly solid components in both adnexa. Cross-sectional CT-scan and magnetic resonance imaging suggested ovarian neoplasm, and they also detected massive peritoneal and pleural effusion. Is that accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's what they told me.
Doctor: Four months after management of hyperstimulation syndrome, due to persistent large ovarian mass and increased tumor marker inhibin more than 3000 pg/mL, you were referred to our oncology department. During your physical examination, they demonstrated enlarged masses extended up to the hypogastric region, which resembled 36 weeks of pregnancy. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what happened.
Doctor: An exploratory laparotomy was performed, which showed massive ascites fluid and multi solid cystic masses in both ovaries extended up to the Xiphoid. They performed a complete resection of the tumor. The pathology report of the frozen section was unable to confirm malignancy, but permanent histology indicated tumor cells with round-to-ovoid nuclei and eosinophilic or vacuolated cytoplasm. Is that what you were informed?
Patient: Yes, that's what they told me.
Doctor: Based on your history and the results of your tests, we will continue to monitor and manage your condition in our oncology department. We'll make sure to provide the best possible care and keep you informed of any updates or changes in your treatment plan.
Patient: Thank you, Doctor. I appreciate all your help and support.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to reach out to us. Take care.

</dialogue>

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I see you're a 65-year-old male with a history of colitis ulcerosa and advanced sarcoidosis, diagnosed 10 years ago. You're currently on oral steroids. What brings you in today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I've been experiencing exertional dyspnea and right ventricular heart failure symptoms for the last 12 months. It's been progressing, and now I'm in functional class IV.
Doctor: I understand. I see that two years ago, you experienced the first severe decompensation of right heart function. At that time, PH was diagnosed on echocardiography. Your RV to LV ratio exceeded one (RV:LV - 39/32 mm), and you had a peak systolic tricuspid regurgitation gradient (TRPG) of 75 mmHg. Your decreased tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion (TAPSE) of 15 mm indicated significant pressure overload and RV systolic dysfunction. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: A chest computed tomography (CT) back then revealed sarcoidosis progression, but no pulmonary thromboemboli were detected. After typical heart failure treatment with diuretics, ACE inhibitors, and an increased steroid dose, you improved and were discharged in WHO functional class II. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I remember that.
Doctor: One year later, you had acute dyspnea, worsening of RV function, and unilateral leg swelling. A chest CT at that time showed fresh thrombi in the left segmental upper lobe pulmonary artery. Moreover, acute deep vein thrombosis was detected with lower limb compression ultrasound. Is that when you started long-term oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban?
Patient: Yeah, that's when I started taking it.
Doctor: Now, two years later, you've been referred to our center due to progressive functional deterioration. On admission, you're in WHO functional class IV, with a saturation on room air of 85%, blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg, and a heart rate of 90 beats per minute. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, those are my current stats.
Doctor: I also see that you have mild peripheral edema present. In your 6-minute walk test, you covered 100 meters with desaturation to 77%. Your plasma natriuretic peptide (NT-pro-BNP) concentration is elevated to 6239 pg/ml, which is quite high (normal range is < 125 pg/ml). Is that accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's what they told me.
Doctor: Your recent echocardiography showed severe RV pressure overload with a TRPG of 95 mmHg, and dilatation of both the right atrium and ventricle. However, your left ventricle morphology and function are preserved. A chest CT scan also showed signs of continued sarcoidosis progression. Is this all correct?
Patient: Yes, doctor. That's what I've been told.
Doctor: Thank you for confirming all this information. We'll continue to monitor your condition and adjust your treatment as needed. It's important to keep taking your medications as prescribed and attend follow-up appointments to ensure the best possible care. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate your help and guidance.
gen_note:

**O: Yes, I understand that your RV function has been declining over the past year.**

He reports experiencing exertional dyspnea and symptoms of right ventricular heart failure for the last 12 months, now in WHO functional class IV. He has a history of severe decompensation of right heart function two years ago with diagnosed pulmonary hypertension (PH) and subsequent acute dyspnea, worsening of RV function, and unilateral leg swelling one year ago.
O: Current vital signs include a saturation on room air of 85%, blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, and heart rate 90 bpm. Physical examination shows mild peripheral edema. A 6-minute walk test covered 100 meters with desaturation to 77%. Laboratory tests reveal elevated NT-pro-BNP at 6239 pg/ml (normal <125 pg/ml). Recent echocardiography indicates severe RV pressure overload with a TRPG of 95 mmHg, and dilatation of both the right atrium and ventricle, but preserved left ventricle morphology and function. Chest CT scan shows signs of continued sarcoidosis progression. No pulmonary thromboemboli detected.
A: The primary diagnosis is advanced sarcoidosis with severe right ventricular heart failure and pulmonary hypertension. Differential diagnoses include exacerbation of underlying heart conditions and potential complications from long-term steroid use. The prognosis is guarded given the progression to WHO functional class IV despite ongoing treatment.
P: Continue current regimen of diuretics, ACE inhibitors, and oral steroids with adjustments as necessary. Maintain long-term oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban. Monitor heart function and sarcoidosis progression closely. Schedule regular follow-up appointments to reassess condition and treatment efficacy. Educate the patient on the importance of medication adherence and symptom monitoring. Consider referral to a specialist in pulmonary hypertension or a heart failure clinic for further evaluation and management.

dialogue:
Doctor: Hello, I'm a doctor from the Department of Medicine, Division of Nephrology at Mantua Hospital. We've been following your treatment for recurrent pyelonephritis. I understand that you're also on oral anticoagulant treatment, Warfarin, for pulmonary embolism and have been diagnosed with stage I obesity, with a BMI of 32.4. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I also see here that you have had a right-sided inguinoscrotal hernia permagna for the past 4 years, but you decided not to get it treated. Can you tell me if you've experienced any symptoms related to this during the last three weeks?
Patient: Yeah, I've been having some issues like dysuria, incomplete urinary bladder emptying, and a reduction of the size of the hernia after voiding. I also noticed increased urination after compressing the scrotal area.
Doctor: I see. Your blood test results show that your haemoglobin is 11.3 g/dl, hematocrit is 34.9%, platelet count is 354 × 109/l, and leukocytosis is 13.5 × 109/l. Additionally, your creatinine level is increased at 1.52 mg/dl, with a urea level of 57 mg/dl, and an international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.39. Your urinalysis demonstrated hematuria, a white cell count of 61/hpf, and the presence of Escherichia coli in your urine culture.
Patient: Oh, that doesn't sound good.
Doctor: Based on these findings, our nephrologist has recommended a surgical evaluation of your hernia. During the physical examination, did you experience any pain or discomfort in your right inguinal and scrotal area, along with swelling in the ipsilateral testicle and scrotum?
Patient: Yes, I did feel pain and discomfort in that area, and there was some swelling too.
Doctor: Your abdomen was also noted to be soft, nontender, and nondistended during the examination. In order to further investigate, we performed a scrotal ultrasound and an abdominal and pelvic CT scan with endovenous contrast. The results revealed a right inguinoscrotal hernia containing the whole urinary bladder and the right pelvic ureter, associated with right hydronephrosis and ipsilateral renal atrophy.
Patient: So, what's the next step?
Doctor: You will be admitted to the Department of Surgery here at Mantua Hospital for treatment of your right-sided inguinoscrotal hernia. Before the surgical intervention, we will replace your Warfarin therapy with therapeutic low molecular weight heparin to ensure your safety during the procedure.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything. I hope the surgery goes well.
Doctor: We will do our best to ensure a successful outcome. If you have any more questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.

</dialogue>

P: The patient will be admitted to the Department of Surgery for surgical treatment of the right-sided inguinoscrotal hernia.
